However, we have not convened all partners at one time. We are waiting to do more outreach and recruitment, especially amongst restaurant owners, in Commerce City before convening/mobilizing.

column77: Local public health agency internal policy
column81: In an effort to model healthy meeting efforts, ACHD's workgroup finalized the draft of our Healthy Meeting Directive. Adams County Health Department (ACHD) uses these standards to showcase our culture in action, with an aim to create meeting environments that prioritize the physical/mental health and productivity of participants while minimizing environmental impact, ultimately contributing to more effective and sustainable workplace practices. The workgroup presented the draft to PHLT for feedback. The directive will soon be approved and implemented in the department with the goal of becoming county wide.

column91: The Arapahoe County Food Security Collaborative had the first official meeting on September 9th with almost 30 participants. The distribution list now includes almost 80 individuals representing emergency food providers, health care, city and county staff, elected officials, health care organizations, K-12 and higher education staff, and residents. Six task forces have been created that are meeting at least monthly to address governance & operations, communications, outreach & engagement, fundraising, programs & projects, and data/evaluation.

column59: The coalition is not going to introduce a policy in 2025. Our aim is to make the case for a sugary beverage tax in Littleton in 2025. City Council members are being educated about food security challenges in Littleton and how funds from a sugary beverage tax could support community members in need and the organizations that provide hunger relief services.
column81: The coalition held a nutrition training on March 10 to educate emergency food providers and other coalition members about the Healthy Eating Research guidelines for food pantries. Food Bank of the Rockies was the featured speaker. A WIC dietician made the case about why providing nutrient dense food is so important for the food insecure population. One coalition member shared about their nutrition guidelines for foods donated and distributed. Four training participants indicated an interest in creating a nutrition policy for their food distribution program. The coalition will provide technical assistance to these organizations.
column89: The coalition was invited to present to the Arapahoe County Board of Health on March 19 and to the Aurora Health Alliance on March 27. Due to the public nature of the Board of Health meeting, information about sugary beverage taxes was lightly referenced. Two board members indicated an interest in meeting following the presentation to discuss how they can support the coalition. The AHA presentation will occur after this report is submitted.
column91: The Arapahoe Food Security Coalition met monthly in Q3 and task forces met monthly as well. The coalition held a nutrition training about guidelines for emergency food providers on March 10 with about 30 participants including emergency food providers, referral agencies, and one Littleton City Council member.  The coalition is currently conducting a capacity assessment for emergency food providers to understand challenges related to food procurement, storage, and distribution, volunteers, kitchen facilities, and funding. The information about funding needs will be used to make the case for a sugary beverage tax in Littleton.  The number of community leaders who are engaging in the coalition has increased dramatically and most are playing an active role in the coalition including serving on task forces and the Leadership Committee, researching grant opportunities, and helping with the emergency food provider capacity assessment interviews.   I attended 3 community events - Cougar Palooza at Charles Hay World School in Englewood, the CU Center for Health Equity Community Engagement Forum, and the coalition's nutrition training.
column112: We are not actively working on a policy so commitments of support are not being pursued.   I have met with 2 Littleton City Council members to gauge their support and have light commitments and indication of interest. One is interested in the nutrition aspect of the SSB tax policy and the other is interested in how it can address food insecurity in his district which has the highest poverty rate.
column118: We are not actively working on a policy campaign so we are not engaging media partners.

column81: Harvest Mountain Farm Garden adopted a Non-Acceptance of In-Kind or Cash Donations from Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Industry. This policy was adopted as a way to support reducing SSBs in our community and to support healthy eating which included nourishing beverages. Harvest Mountain Farm Garden recognizes that hydration plays a vital role in our health and choosing healthy drinks supports our bodies, prevents chronic disease, and contributed to overall well-being.

column81: Love Bears All passed a nutrition policy following attendance at the Nutrition training in March 2025. With assistance from Laura Backhaus, coalition member and WIC Dietitian, the policy aims to improve the nutritional quality of foods distributed. This comes at a time when the organization is increasing capacity to distribute perishable foods.   CAFE 180 is in the process of creating a policy with support from the WIC Dietitian.  Integrated Family Community Services is piloting the Supporting Wellness at Pantries food labeling program as the result of participation at the nutrition training. Action to create a nutrition policy has not started.

column81: No additional policy efforts have been passed this quarter.

column91: Coalition meetings happened 8/21 and 10/1
column112: We created a letter of support for the Healthy Drinks in Kids' Meals (HDKM) ordinance to the Commerce City Council. It outlines the health risks of sugary drink consumption, the policy's benefits for children, families, and businesses, and emphasizes that it preserves choice while making healthy options the default. The letter includes the names and logos of supporting organizations and partners. We've included 2 new logos on our letter this quarter.
column118: This quarter, we created a social media calendar. It includes different monthly observances, content in English and Spanish and a call to action specific for our campaign and coalition.
